If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.

evidence.pdf_reference: that the photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 does not occur by absorption of the 410 and 570 nm peaks attributed to the d-d transition.When UV light is irradiated onto Zn-Cr LDH, electron-hole pairs are generated.CO 2 is reduced to CO by two photogenerated electrons.In this reaction process, a reduction in electron-hole recombination is necessary for enhancement of the photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 .Co-catalysts such as Pt, Pd, and Au act not only to reduce electron-hole recombination but also to enhance

Zn-Cr layered double hydroxide (Zn-Cr LDH) and noble metal (Pt, Pd, Au) loaded Zn-Cr LDHs were prepared, and the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was evaluated.All samples exhibited photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to CO under UV irradiation.Among them, 0.1 mass Pt-loaded LDH exhibited the highest performance.This is attributed to the fact that noble metals act as a co-catalysts, not only for the reduction of recombination of electrons and holes, but also for the enhancement of multi-electron reductive

the other samples.These results indicate that the photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 is enhanced by addition of the co-catalysts, and there is an optimum amount of co-catalyst that can be loaded on Zn-Cr LDH. The specific surface area (SSA) of Zn-Cr LDH, 0.1 mass Ptloaded, 0.1 mass Pd-loaded, and 0.7 mass Au-loaded LDHs, which exhibited the highest CO evolution among the Pt-, Pd-, and Au-LDHs, was 73, 61, 88, and 50 m 2 g, respectively.The photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 for these LDHs was normalized by

Zn-Cr LDH (ZnCr molar ratio142) samples were prepared by a coprecipitation method, and noble metal loaded Zn-Cr LDH samples were prepared by the photochemical deposition method.The photocatalytic reactions were performed in a top-irradiation-type quartz glass vessel at room temperature.Before the photocatalytic tests, the samples were irradiated in air using UV light for 2 days to clear the ubiquitous organic pollutants from the surface.For the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test, 0.05 g of the sample was

but also to enhance multi-electron reductive reactions.Since CO is formed by a two-electron reduction reaction of CO 2 , the Pt-, Pd-, and Au-LDHs exhibit higher photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 to CO due to the enhancement of the twoelectron reductive reaction.Pt-loaded LDH exhibited higher performance than Pd-and Au-loaded LDH.Since the reaction occurs on the surface of the co-catalysts, size of the co-catalysts is an important factor.Since the size of Pt is smaller than that of Pd or Au, and the number

samples, with a value 13 times larger than that for Zn-Cr LDH. The mechanism of photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 is complex in layered double hydroxides.Thus, it is difficult to carry out a direct comparison of the performance with other photocatalysts.Here, we suggest a possible mechanism for photocatalytic conversion of CO 2 over Zn-Cr LDH.Since, when visible light (4370 nm, Xe lamp with cut filter) is irradiated onto the Zn-Cr LDH samples, CO is not detected, we considered that the photocatalytic

Zn-Cr LDH (ZnCr molar ratio142) samples were prepared by a coprecipitation method, and noble metal loaded Zn-Cr LDH samples were prepared by the photochemical deposition method.The photocatalytic reactions were performed in a top-irradiation-type quartz glass vessel at room temperature.Before the photocatalytic tests, the samples were irradiated in air using UV light for 2 days to clear the ubiquitous organic pollutants from the surface.For the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test, 0.05 g of the sample was

test, 0.05 g of the sample was placed in the vessel.High purity CO 2 gas (99.995) was bubbled into ultrapure water, after which the mixed CO 2 and water vapor gases were flowed into the vessel for 15 min (Fig. S1).After flowing, the vessel was closed, and it was placed beneath 200 W Hg-Xe lamps (LA-410UV-5, Hayashi Watch-Works, Japan).The concentration of carbon monoxide (CO) was monitored by gas chromatography with nitrogen as the carrier gas (GC-2014AF, Shimadzu, 2 m Porapak-Q column ZP-17 and flame

Fig. 2 shows that the amount of CO evolved in the presence of Zn-Cr LDH under UV irradiation increased linearly with irradiation time.Since no CO evolution was detected in the dark, it can be concluded that photocatalytic conversion CO 2 to CO proceeded under UV irradiation. Fig. 3 shows the amount of CO evolved in the presence of Pt-, Pd-, and Au-LDHs after 3 h of UV irradiation, where the black dotted line indicates the case for Zn-Cr LDH.In all samples, CO was evolved under UV irradiation, and the
